Upon her brain, and make her clench her hands,
On Calvary, in noonday’s burning heat.
Gold, frankincense and myrrh. The Magi kneel
The church was fairly full. Evensong, nowadays, was always better attended than morning service.

“All children are the same. They always invent a ‘friend’ to play with.”
“At five, perhaps. Not when they’re thirteen,” said Janet bitterly.
“Try not to mind, dear,” said Gertrude gently.
Mary was careful not to disturb him. She busied herself in getting together the midday meal.

Ever seeking, ever sighing,
Through the night to noon.
I am he all lovers know!

Ever fearing, ever sighing,
Through the night to noon.
Every lover hears my cry,

And the Men of the Desert turn to the East
At the hour of the Midday prayer.
Their weariness stayed and refreshed,

Calvary
ON Calvary, in midday’s burning heat,
What thoughts in Mary’s heart, as pale she stands?
